items.title: Trump says all trade negotiations with Canada ‘terminated’ over an anti-tariff advertising campaign – US politics live
items.standfirst: The US president announced he ended talks in retaliation to an ad featuring Ronald Reagan speaking negatively about tariffsThe New York state attorney general, Letitia James, is expected to plead not guilty on Friday to charges of bank fraud and false statements brought after Donald Trump publicly called for her to be prosecuted in a move widely seen as political retribution.James is scheduled to made her first appearance in the case and be arraigned in federal district court in Virginia before US magistrate judge Jamar Walker at 11am ET, according to court documents. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says all Canada trade talks ‘terminated’ over ad criticising tariffs
items.standfirst: US president accuses Canada of ‘egregious behaviour’ after release of ad featuring Ronald Reagan criticising tariffsDonald Trump has announced an immediate end to “all trade negotiations” with Canada over a television advert opposing US tariffs that quoted the former US president Ronald Reagan.The advert, which was paid for by the government of the Canadian province of Ontario, uses excerpts of a 1987 speech where Reagan says “trade barriers hurt every American worker”. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

Trump called the ad "fake" on Truth Social, leading to the cancellation.

items.title: Trump pardons Binance crypto founder Changpeng Zhao
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Thursday pardoned Binance co-founder Changpeng “CZ” Zhao, who was convicted of violating anti-money-laundering laws, the White House said. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt accused former president Joe Biden of being “very hostile” to the crypto industry. Zhao served four months in prison after his 2023 guilty plea.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday pardoned Binance co-founder Changpeng “CZ” Zhao, who was convicted of violating anti-money-laundering laws, the White House said. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt accused former president Joe Biden of being “very hostile” to the crypto industry. Zhao served four months in prison after his 2023 guilty plea.

items.title: Trump pardons founder of Binance, world’s largest crypto exchange
items.standfirst: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...
items.content: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...

items.content: Zhao was sentenced to four months in prison in 2024 after pleading guilty to violating money laundering laws.

items.title: ‘War on Crypto Is Over’: Donald Trump Pardons Binance Founder CZ
items.standfirst: After serving a federal prison sentence for violating anti-money-laundering laws and US sanctions, former crypto exchange CEO Changpeng Zhao has been pardoned by US president Donald Trump.
items.content: After serving a federal prison sentence for violating anti-money-laundering laws and US sanctions, former crypto exchange CEO Changpeng Zhao has been pardoned by US president Donald Trump.

ai_summary: Donald Trump pardoned Changpeng Zhao, founder of Binance, a crypto exchange.
Zhao was convicted of violating anti-money laundering laws in 2023.
He served four months in prison before the pardon was issued.
The White House stated the pardon was an exercise of presidential authority.
The White House accused Joe Biden of being hostile to the crypto industry.

items.title: Putin says he will never bow to US but concedes sanctions may cause ‘some losses’
items.standfirst: China and India likely to scale back Russian oil imports as Trump tries to bring an end to war in UkraineVladimir Putin has said Russia will never bow to US pressure but conceded new sanctions could cause some economic pain, as China and India were reported to be scaling back Russian oil imports after Washington targeted Moscow’s two largest producers.The US on Wednesday imposed sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, as well as nearly three dozen of their subsidiaries, as the Trump administration increased pressure on the Kremlin to negotiate an end to its war against Ukraine. The EU separately agreed to a phased ban on the import of Russian liquefied natural gas, and added two Chinese oil refiners to its Russian sanctions list. Continue reading...
items.content: China and India likely to scale back Russian oil imports as Trump tries to bring an end to war in UkraineVladimir Putin has said Russia will never bow to US pressure but conceded new sanctions could cause some economic pain, as China and India were reported to be scaling back Russian oil imports after Washington targeted Moscow’s two largest producers.The US on Wednesday imposed sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, as well as nearly three dozen of their subsidiaries, as the Trump administration increased pressure on the Kremlin to negotiate an end to its war against Ukraine. The EU separately agreed to a phased ban on the import of Russian liquefied natural gas, and added two Chinese oil refiners to its Russian sanctions list. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin defiant in response to U.S. sanctions
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized new U.S. sanctions against Russian oil companies but said they would not “significantly affect our economic wellbeing.” He also questioned President Trump’s decision to cancel a meeting in Hungary, saying dialogue is better than “disputes, or especially war.”
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized new U.S. sanctions against Russian oil companies but said they would not “significantly affect our economic wellbeing.” He also questioned President Trump’s decision to cancel a meeting in Hungary, saying dialogue is better than “disputes, or especially war.”

items.title: Oil price jumps and FTSE 100 hits new high after Trump puts sanctions on Russian firms
items.standfirst: Assets in US belonging to Rosneft and Lukoil frozen as shares in Shell and BP rise by 3%Business live – latest updatesOil prices jumped and energy companies helped the FTSE 100 to a record high after Donald Trump announced new sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil producers.Brent crude increased by 5.7% to $66.13 a barrel after the news of the fresh restrictions on Rosneft and Lukoil, as the US president ramps up pressure on Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine. Continue reading...
items.content: Assets in US belonging to Rosneft and Lukoil frozen as shares in Shell and BP rise by 3%Business live – latest updatesOil prices jumped and energy companies helped the FTSE 100 to a record high after Donald Trump announced new sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil producers.Brent crude increased by 5.7% to $66.13 a barrel after the news of the fresh restrictions on Rosneft and Lukoil, as the US president ramps up pressure on Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. sanctions Russia's two largest oil companies
items.standfirst: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.
items.content: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.

ai_summary: High-level U.S.-China talks are expected before a meeting next week.
U.S. sanctions on Russian energy firms may hinder trade agreements.
Vladimir Putin said Russia will not bow to U.S. pressure.
China and India may reduce Russian oil imports due to sanctions.
Putin questioned Trump's decision to cancel a meeting in Hungary.

items.title: It's supposed to be payday for many federal workers. Instead, they're getting nothing
items.standfirst: Roughly 1.4 million federal workers are going without pay due to the government shutdown. About half of them are furloughed, while the other half has been deemed essential and is working without pay.
items.content: Roughly 1.4 million federal workers are going without pay due to the government shutdown. About half of them are furloughed, while the other half has been deemed essential and is working without pay.(Image credit: Tyrone Turner/WAMU)

items.standfirst: The government shutdown stretched into Day 24 on Friday as the Senate failed to advance a measure to pay some federal workers.
items.content: The government shutdown stretched into Day 24 on Friday as the Senate failed to advance a measure to pay some federal workers.

ai_summary: The government shutdown entered its 24th day on Friday.
Fears are mounting about the impact of the funding lapse.
The Senate failed to pass a bill to pay some federal workers.
Approximately 1.4 million federal workers are without pay.
Half of the workers are furloughed, and half are working without pay.

items.title: NBA coach and player arrested in massive mafia-linked sports rigging and gambling probe
items.standfirst: FBI Director Kash Patel announced charges in a massive mafia-linked gambling and sports rigging probe that led to the arrests of Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier and Portland Trail Blazers head coach Chauncey Billups. Simon Moritz has this story.
items.content: FBI Director Kash Patel announced charges in a massive mafia-linked gambling and sports rigging probe that led to the arrests of Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier and Portland Trail Blazers head coach Chauncey Billups. Simon Moritz has this story.

items.title: NBA gambling arrests stun league, expose mafia links: What to know
items.standfirst: A total of 34 people were arrested, including Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier, and former player Damon Jones.
items.content: A total of 34 people were arrested, including Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier, and former player Damon Jones.

items.title: Miami Heat's Terry Rozier charged in illegal sports betting case, FBI says
items.standfirst: The Miami Heat guard was arrested in Orlando in a federal sports betting case that prosecutors say involved using confidential NBA information to place illegal wagers.
items.content: The Miami Heat guard was arrested in Orlando in a federal sports betting case that prosecutors say involved using confidential NBA information to place illegal wagers.

items.title: NBA's Rozier and Billups among dozens of arrests in illegal betting probe
items.standfirst: Among those taken into custody in the betting investigation today are Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier of the Miami Heat and former NBA player Damon Jones.
items.content: Among those taken into custody in the betting investigation today are Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier of the Miami Heat and former NBA player Damon Jones.

items.title: What to know about prop bets, and their role in the NBA gambling case
items.standfirst: Dozens of people, including Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups and Miami Heat player Terry Rozier, have been arrested and charged in connection with two federal probes into an alleged widespread sports betting scheme and an organized crime ring. Prosecutors accuse Rozier of working with a betting ring to influence prop bets. CBS News reporter Elaine Quijano breaks down what prop bets are.
items.content: Dozens of people, including Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups and Miami Heat player Terry Rozier, have been arrested and charged in connection with two federal probes into an alleged widespread sports betting scheme and an organized crime ring. Prosecutors accuse Rozier of working with a betting ring to influence prop bets. CBS News reporter Elaine Quijano breaks down what prop bets are.

ai_summary: FBI announced arrests in a mafia-linked sports rigging and gambling probe.
Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier and Portland coach Chauncey Billups were arrested.
A total of 34 people were arrested in the illegal betting case.
Prosecutors allege Rozier influenced prop bets with a betting ring.
Former NBA player Damon Jones was also among those arrested.

items.standfirst: CEO says fiscal discipline should be balanced with ‘policies that create stability, consistency and support growth’NatWest Group’s chief executive has warned the government against increasing taxes on banks in the autumn budget, as the high street lender reported a 30% jump in profits.Paul Thwaite said he understood the “difficult choices” that the chancellor, Rachel Reeves, had to make in order to help close a potential £30bn shortfall in the public finances but argued she needed to “balance fiscal discipline” with “policies that create stability, consistency and support growth”. clusters.title: Vance and Rubio criticise Israeli parliament's vote on West Bank annexation
clusters.neutral_headline: U.S. Pressure on Israel Over West Bank

items.title: Vance and Rubio criticise Israeli parliament's vote on West Bank annexation
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio arrived in Israel on Thursday and met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as US President Donald Trump said Israel would lose US support if it went ahead with possible plans to annex the West Bank. Rubio is the latest high-profile member of Trump's cabinet to visit Israel in a bid to shore up the fragile US-brokered ceasefire in Gaza. France24's James Vasina and Alexandra Quarini tell us more.
items.content: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio arrived in Israel on Thursday and met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as US President Donald Trump said Israel would lose US support if it went ahead with possible plans to annex the West Bank. Rubio is the latest high-profile member of Trump's cabinet to visit Israel in a bid to shore up the fragile US-brokered ceasefire in Gaza. France24's James Vasina and Alexandra Quarini tell us more.

items.title: US pressures Israel on West Bank as Rubio begins visit
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio arrived in Israel on Thursday and met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as US President Donald Trump said Israel would lose US support if it went ahead with possible plans to annex the West Bank. Rubio is the latest high-profile member of Trump's cabinet to visit Israel in a bid to shore up the fragile US-brokered ceasefire in Gaza. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.
items.content: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio arrived in Israel on Thursday and met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as US President Donald Trump said Israel would lose US support if it went ahead with possible plans to annex the West Bank. Rubio is the latest high-profile member of Trump's cabinet to visit Israel in a bid to shore up the fragile US-brokered ceasefire in Gaza. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.

items.title: Vance says Knesset votes on annexing West Bank are an ‘insult’ as Netanyahu halts progress
items.standfirst: US vice-president suggests votes were ‘stupid political stunt’ as Israeli PM orders a stop to any further work on bills The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has ordered a halt to the advancement of parliamentary bills linked to the annexation of the West Bank after the US vice-president, JD Vance, described a vote on two bills in the Knesset as an “insult”.The bills applying Israeli law to the occupied West Bank, which would be tantamount to the annexation of land Palestinians want for a state, won preliminary approval from Israel’s parliament on Wednesday, barely a week after Donald Trump pushed through a deal aimed at ending a two-year Israeli offensive in Gaza. Continue reading...
items.content: US vice-president suggests votes were ‘stupid political stunt’ as Israeli PM orders a stop to any further work on bills The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has ordered a halt to the advancement of parliamentary bills linked to the annexation of the West Bank after the US vice-president, JD Vance, described a vote on two bills in the Knesset as an “insult”.The bills applying Israeli law to the occupied West Bank, which would be tantamount to the annexation of land Palestinians want for a state, won preliminary approval from Israel’s parliament on Wednesday, barely a week after Donald Trump pushed through a deal aimed at ending a two-year Israeli offensive in Gaza. Continue reading...

ai_summary: U.S. officials criticized Israeli parliament votes on West Bank annexation.
Marco Rubio met with Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel.
Donald Trump said Israel could lose U.S. support.
JD Vance called the Knesset votes an "insult."
Netanyahu halted further work on annexation-related bills.

items.title: Meta found in breach of EU law over ‘ineffective’ complaints system for flagging illegal content
items.standfirst: European Commission initial finding says Facebook and Instagram introduced unnecessary steps for users to submit reportsInstagram and Facebook have breached EU law by failing to provide users with simple ways to complain or flag illegal content, including child sexual abuse material and terrorist content, the European Commission has said.In a preliminary finding on Friday, the EU’s executive body said Meta, the $1.8tn California company that runs the social media services, had introduced unnecessary steps in processes for users to submit reports. Continue reading...

items.title: Ireland votes for next president as polls predict landslide for Catherine Connolly
items.standfirst: Leftwing independent widely expected to succeed Michael D Higgins, but fears grow over low turnout and spoilt ballots Irish voters are going to the polls to elect a new president, with final opinion polls predicting a landslide for Catherine Connolly, an outspoken leftwing independent who has captured the imagination of many younger people.An opinion poll on Thursday gave Connolly 40% versus 25% for her opponent, Heather Humphreys, a former cabinet minister. When the figures were adjusted for those who are undecided or plan to spoil their vote, Connolly had 55% and Humphreys 35%. Continue reading...
items.content: Leftwing independent widely expected to succeed Michael D Higgins, but fears grow over low turnout and spoilt ballots Irish voters are going to the polls to elect a new president, with final opinion polls predicting a landslide for Catherine Connolly, an outspoken leftwing independent who has captured the imagination of many younger people.An opinion poll on Thursday gave Connolly 40% versus 25% for her opponent, Heather Humphreys, a former cabinet minister. When the figures were adjusted for those who are undecided or plan to spoil their vote, Connolly had 55% and Humphreys 35%. Continue reading...
